bibl.title: Memorandum from Albert E. Truby to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 25, 1930

div1.p: Truby's recounts his memories of the yellow fever experiments, and his anger with Agramonte for making what he feels are unjustified claims.

div1.head: Memorandum from Albert E. Truby to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 25, 1930
div1.p:
When it became known that the Spanish immigrants were not satisfact-
ory to Major Reed for his experiments on yellow fever, several members of the
Hospital Corps detachment at Camp Columbia volunteered for this work. Those
of us at Camp Columbia considered this one of the most heroic events in history
since all of these men had been in Cuba and knew from experience at the
hospital what it meant to contract yellow fever. They had been through the
epidemic and had seen the high mortality caused by this disease among our
officers at Quemados and Havana. Furthermore at this time the officers and
men on duty at the hospital, including these volunteers, were all convinced
that the mosquito was the agent that transmitted yellow fever to Lazear,
Carroll and XY. There was no reward offered to these men at that time.
They admired and respected Major Reed and volunteered because they felt that
the positive proof needed to substantiate the mosquito theory could not be
obtained in any other way. Later on Major Reed found that he could give them
a gratuity from the funds which had been allotted to him for this work, and he
decided to offer it to them. I am positive however that this money gratuity
offered no inducement to any of these men.

I was in command of the detachment when Major Reed selected the
site for Camp Lazear. Dr. Roger Post Ames and I went with Major Reed when
he first inspected the site, and if I am not mistaken you were with us or
went over to see the site before it was finally selected. As you know, it
was not “we” (Agramonte, Reed and Carroll) who did these things. It was
Major Reed alone, and it makes my blood boil to have the last surviving
member of that board, and the one whom Reed knewused so little, make such an
effort to detract from Reed's work.

I certainly concur in your letter, but if I were writing it I would
make it stronger and point out some statements he has made which are not in
accordance with facts. Agramonte never saw XY, and he knew nothing about him
until Reed published his preliminary report. He did not see Lazear during
his illness and I doubt if he was present at the funeral. As Commanding
Officer of the hospital the arrangements for that funeral fell to me and I
have a very clear recollection of the occasion and my fight with Captain
Goodale, Quartermaster, who did not want us to use the flag, as it would ruin
it to be disinfected, and also my difficulties with Colonel Baldwin, the Com-
manding Officer of Camp Columbia, over the band and the chaplain All these
circumstances are still fresh in my memory. Of course I do not wish to start
anything at this time, but as you know, there are a few of us left who know the
details. Outside of the enlisted men who took part in the experiments the only
living officers who knew what went on at that time are you and Dr. Pinto and
myself.
div1.closer:
Albert E. Truby
Colonel, Medical Corps,
Executive Officer.
